oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of Olivet Presbyterian Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On April 26, 1886, Olivet Presbyterian Church was organized and the stone church on Howard Avenue was dedicated on April 12, 1891.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of First Moravian German Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The First Moravian Church was organized in 1854 and a frame structure was built on Cooper street and consecrated on September 10, 1856. In 1891 that building was demolished and replaced by this brick building

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A feature of the church was the tree growing from the turret on the right. THe church was sold to the Citizen's Trust Company in 1914. A feature of the church was the tree growing from the turret on the right. THe church was sold to the Citizen's Trust Company in 1914.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of Calvary Episcopal Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Church was incorporated in December 15, 1850. In 1851, a wooden church was build on South Street between Neilson and Howard Avenue. In 1868, the lot on the corner of South Street and Howard Avenue was purchased and construction of a stone church began. The first service was held December 10, 1872.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: St Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: St. Paul's evangelical Lutheran Church was organized in May 1860. In 1868, the construction of a church building was commenced and completed. A hurricane in 1880 damaged the building so it had to be torn down and replaced with this new edifice.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of Holy Cross Episcopal Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Memorial Church of the Holy Cross was opened as a mission of the Grace Church in 1871. The cornerstone of the stone church on Bleeker street was laid in October 9, 1890. It opened October 28, 1891 and was consecrated by Bishop Huntington on January 5, 1892

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of Tabernacle Baptist Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In June 1864, the Broad Street Baptist Church voted to move to a more central location in the city. In October of that year, it re-incorporated as "Tabernacle Baptist Church" and on August 3, 1865, the cornerstone was laid for the new church building on the corner of Hopper and King Streets.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of Centenary Methodist Episcopal Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The East utica methodist Episcopal Church was organized in 1880. In January 1884, a wooden church was erected on the corner of Lansing and Nichols streets. In 1913 a large tile and stucco church was build on the corner of Rutger and Nichols Streets.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of St. John's Roman Catholic Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: St. John's was organized in 1819. The first wooden church was erected on the site in 1821 and was replaced with a stone church in 1839. This third church building was built in 1869.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of Dryer Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A new congregation of Methodists was organized in West Utica in 1867. A chapel was built on the corner of Court and Stark streets. In 1886 the name "Dryer Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church" was adopted. This building was abandoned in 1917 when the society moved to the old Court street school on the corner of Court and Lenox Avenue.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This Religious Society was organized on May 22 1893. On June 28th of the same year, Julius Fulmer and others gave the society a deed to the property on Roberts Street and this church was built. This society dissolved on Dec. 11, 1924

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of St. Luke's Episcopal Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: St' Luke's episcopal Church was a mission of Grace Church in 1869. A stone church was built on property adjoining St. Luke's Hospital and consecrated in 1876. This building was the home of St. Luke's Church until 1918. In that year, the church moved to Matthews Avenue.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of Park Baptist Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Bleeker Street Baptist Church was moved in 1888 to Stuben Park and re-named "Park Baptist Church" in its new building. The congregation merged with Tabernacle Baptist Church in 1930. The building was abandoned and razed for a proposed addition to the State Armory. This never materialized.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of First Free Methodist Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A "Free Methodist Church" was organized in 1863 and occupied a small wooden church on the corner of South and Miller streets. By 1880, the congregation had outgrown this building and, during the pastorate of Rev. D. Mowers, a new brick church was erected on Chatham street, now Linwood Place. On July 30, 1946, lighting destroyed the top of the steeple.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of Plymouth Congregational Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On May 13, 1883, Congregational services for 40 people were begun in the city's common council chamber. After deciding to form a Congregational Society, the group was organized in September 1883 as the Plymouth Church. In 1884 the property was purchased for $14,000 at the corner of Plant and State. In 1905 a larger stone church was build at a cost of $70,000. This church was dedicated in June 1906. A church house was built in 1928 that in 1946 was used as temporary quarters for the newly organized Utica College. Pictured is the 1885 chapel. Edwards, E. (2007) Around Utica. Arcadia Publishing. Charleston SC
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Manning, A.J.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Protestant churches; Steeples; Clerestories;
Philosophy & Religion; Architecture;

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This Church was built in 1886 and used until 1920 when the congregation merged with First Methodist Episcopal Church to form Central ME Church The building was sold to Temple Beth El as a synagogue and was used for some years. Remains of the building can be seen

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of Christ Dutch Reform Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Christ Church was organized in 1830 and worshipped in a church on Broad street until 1866 when a new church was erected on the corner of Genesee street and Cornalia Place. This was destroyed by fire in 1881 and was rebuilt and opened in 1882. This church dissolved about 1950

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of East Utica Moravian Sunday School
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The First Moravian Church society in 1882 started a Sunday School on South street, just opposite Leeds Street. From this small beginning, a mission church known as the Second Moravian Church was established in 1912 in the small wooden school The name was changed in 1913 to Trinity Moravian Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Manning, A.J.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sunday Schools; Moravian Churches; Wooden buildings;
Sunday School Buildings;
Philosophy & Religion; Education;
